newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Briton in Malaysia custody case given visit rights.
newsitem.headline: Briton in Malaysia custody case given visit rights.

text.p: A British woman embroiled in a child custody battle with her estranged Malaysian husband obtained on Tuesday a Moslem court order that permits her to visit her son without interference from the father.

Jane Brummit, also known by her Moslem name of Aishah Jane Abdullah, alleged that Ismail Ariffin physically abused her recently when she visited their 20-month-old son, Sunni Sazali, the national Bernama news agency reported on Tuesday.

Brummit was granted the order by a Syariah Court in northern Penang state, where the couple were married in 1994 and had lived before their break-up. Ismail was not represented by counsel in the court, Bernama said.

The 26-year-old Briton from Winchester, who converted to Islam, filed an application for a divorce from Ismail on December 3 after he travelled to Britain in October and brought their son back to Malaysia.
She is also seeking custody of Sunni, who is currently being cared for by Ismail's family in Penang.
Ahmad Munawir Abdul Aziz, Brummit's lawyer, told reporters on Tuesday that the court gave Ismail, 29, a month to reply and fixed March 4 for submissions from both parties.
Brummit said that as Sunni was now under the care of Ismail's family, the court had ordered that the child remain there pending the outcome of the case, Bernama said.
Ismail, a freelance artist, had accused Brummit and her mother of taking Sunni to England via Thailand without his knowledge in March this year.
